sen.cmt: （裁判員の～）の部分の訳漏れ。文全体の構成を修正しました。
sen.e: In addition, Karyo imposed on Saiban-in (Lay Judge) (or prospective lay judges) due to false statements and a violation on duty of appearance under Saiban-in System is considered as chokai-batsu. (The Law of Criminal Suit in which Lay Judge participated, Article 82, 83.)

sen.j: 法制史における過料
sen.e: Non-penal fine (Karyo) in history of law
Karyo in history of legislation.
sen.cmt: Non-penal fineを除き、law→legislation としました。
sen.e: Karyo in history of legislation.

sen.j: ところが、中世・近世の日本では軽微な財産刑を指して「過料」と呼称している。
sen.e: However, during medieval and the early-modern times in Japan, a negligible punishment by seizing of assets was called "Karyo (過料)."
However, during medieval and the early-modern times in Japan, a negligible punishment by seizing assets was called 'Karyo.'
sen.cmt: seizing of assets→seizing assetsとして、（過料）の日本語表記を除きました。
sen.e: However, during medieval and the early-modern times in Japan, a negligible punishment by seizing assets was called 'Karyo.'

sen.j: これは現在の科料や罰金に相当する処分・刑罰も含んでおり、刑罰の1種にあたるものである。
sen.e: A negligible punishment by the seizing of assets is fact the punishment was to include current punishment (or penalty) and a penal punishment ("keibatsu" in Japanese) such as petty fines (Karyo, 科料) and penal fines ("bakkin" in Japanese); therefore, a minor punishment by the seizing of assets is a kind of a penal punishment.
It includes a punishment and a penalty corresponding current petty fines and penal fines; therefore, it is a kind of a penal punishment.
sen.cmt: 主語をIt とし、日本語表記や補足等を除き、文を修正しました。
sen.e: It includes a punishment and a penalty corresponding current petty fines and penal fines; therefore, it is a kind of a penal punishment.

sen.j: 律令法において罰金を課する贖銅制度が存在していたが、律令法が衰退して刑罰が緩やかになった。
sen.e: The Ritsuryo law established the Shokudo [Pecuniary penalty (fine), which was paid with copper coins] system to impose punishment and for collection of penal fines, but later the Ritsuryo law enforcement power revoked, resulting in less strict penal punishments.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Ritsuryo law established the Shokudo (penalty charges which was paid with copper coins) system to impose punishment and for collection of penal fines, but later the Ritsuryo law enforcement power revoked, resulting in less strict penal punishments.
sen.cmt: Pecuniary penalty→penalty charges とし、括弧内を修正しました。
sen.e: The Ritsuryo law established the Shokudo (penalty charges which was paid with copper coins) system to impose punishment and for collection of penal fines, but later the Ritsuryo law enforcement power revoked, resulting in less strict penal punishments.

sen.j: 軽微な犯罪を「過怠」と称して実刑の代わりに金銭などを徴収して神社や寺院、道路、橋梁などの修繕費用の一部とした。
sen.e: Meanwhile, law enforcements or administrative governments called minor crimes "katai (negligence),"; so instead of imposing a jail sentence, law enforcement or administrative governments collected money, then utilized the collected money for the toward the cost of repairing shrines, temples, road and bridges.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: A minor crime was called 'katai (negligence),' which was utilized for the toward the cost of repairing shrines, temples, road and bridges by collecting money instead of imposing a prison sentence.
sen.cmt: Meanwhile～called を除き、文全体の構成を修正しました。jail →prison としました。
sen.e: A minor crime was called 'katai (negligence),' which was utilized for the toward the cost of repairing shrines, temples, road and bridges by collecting money instead of imposing a prison sentence.

sen.j: このことて神仏や社会に対する反省の証とした。
sen.e: This publicly administered punishment was interpreted as an apology for the criminal's past conduct against God, Buddha, and society.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It provided proof of an apology against Gods, Buddha, and society.
sen.cmt: This～as→It とし、for the criminal’s past conduct を除きました。
sen.e: It provided proof of an apology against Gods, Buddha, and society.

sen.j: この際に支払われた金銭を「過怠銭」「過怠料」などと称し、後にこれを略して「過銭」「過料」とも呼んだ。
sen.e: The payment of punishment fines is called, "Katai-sen" and "Katai-ryo," later this would be shortened and called, "Kasen" and "Karyo."
The payment of punishment fines was called 'Katai-sen' and 'Katai-ryo,' later this was shortened and called 'Kasen' and 'Karyo.'
sen.cmt: クオーテーションマークを修正、is→was としました。
sen.e: The payment of punishment fines was called 'Katai-sen' and 'Katai-ryo,' later this was shortened and called 'Kasen' and 'Karyo.'

sen.j: 御成敗式目第15条において裁判で虚偽の証言したことが発覚した者に対して寺社の修理を命じている。
sen.e: Under the Goseibai-shikimoku (code of conduct for samurai), Article 15 stated, "A samurai was found to commit perjury (making a forged statement) during a trial shall be ordered to repair temples."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In Goseibai-shikimoku (code of conduct for samurai), Article 15, a person who was found to commit perjury at a trial was ordered to repair temples and shrines.
sen.cmt: Under→In, samurai→person, としました。「裁判で」の訳漏れ、at a trialを加え、and shrinesが抜けていました。
sen.e: In Goseibai-shikimoku (code of conduct for samurai), Article 15, a person who was found to commit perjury at a trial was ordered to repair temples and shrines.

sen.j: これを補うために出された追加法においても、「過代物」（寛元2年（1244年）第231条）・「過料」（建長5年（1253年）第292条）の名称が用いられている。
sen.e: In addition, supplementary articles were issued comprising this order of Article 15, those articles included the term of Karyo or a similar name: "Kadibutsu" (Article 231, in year 1244) and "Karyo" (Article 292, in year 1253).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the supplementary articles issued to cover the Article 15, the terms of 'Kajibutsu' (Article 231, in 1244) and 'Karyo' (Article 292, in 1253) were used.
sen.cmt: In addition, those～included, similar name, year, 余分なスペース等を除き、compriseing→to cover としました。
sen.e: In the supplementary articles issued to cover the Article 15, the terms of 'Kajibutsu' (Article 231, in 1244) and 'Karyo' (Article 292, in 1253) were used.

sen.j: 「過料」や「過怠銭」またはそれに類する内容の財産刑は荘園における本所法や戦国大名における分国法、あるいは民間における法慣習としても行われていた。
sen.e: "Karyo," "Katai-sen," and other similar terms of punishment through the seizing assets were enforced under several laws and regulations: The Honjo (proprietor or guarantor of manor) law which dealt with shoen (manor in medieval Japan): The Bunkokuho (the law individual sengoku-daimyo enforced within their own domain) which dealt with daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) in the Sengoku period: The customary laws for commoners.

Karyo,' 'Katai-sen' and other similar punishments by the seizing assets were enforced under the Honjo (proprietor or guarantor of manor) law which dealt with shoen (manor in medieval Japan), the Bunkokuho (the law individual sengoku-daimyo enforced within their own domain) which dealt with daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) in the Sengoku period and the customary laws for commoners.
sen.cmt: terms of punishment through→punishment byとし, : The～→, the として文をつなげました。
sen.e: Karyo,' 'Katai-sen' and other similar punishments by the seizing assets were enforced under the Honjo (proprietor or guarantor of manor) law which dealt with shoen (manor in medieval Japan), the Bunkokuho (the law individual sengoku-daimyo enforced within their own domain) which dealt with daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) in the Sengoku period and the customary laws for commoners.

sen.j: 江戸幕府においては『科条類典』に享保3年（1718年）に白紙の手形と引換とした借金契約を結ばせた貸主に初めて過料を課したという記述があることから、徳川吉宗の享保の改革の一環として過料が導入されたという学説が存在していた。
sen.e: During Edo Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) ruling period, there was a written statement "For the first time, in order to comply with 'Kajoruiten (a collection of classified regulations and laws),' a lender was imposed a punishment of a Karyo for making an agreement with a debt (loan) contract with a borrower by using an empty promissory note (a usury: without written terms and conditions) in 1718."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: During Edo Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) ruling period, "Kajoruiten" (a collection of classified regulations and laws) mentioned that Karyo was imposed on a lender who made a debt contract by using an empty promissory note the first time in 1718, therefore, there was a theory that Yoshimune TOKUGAWA introduced Karyo as a part of Kyoho-no-kaikaku (Kyoho reform).
sen.cmt: there was～以降、文全体の構成を修正しました。
sen.e: During Edo Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) ruling period, "Kajoruiten" (a collection of classified regulations and laws) mentioned that Karyo was imposed on a lender who made a debt contract by using an empty promissory note the first time in 1718, therefore, there was a theory that Yoshimune TOKUGAWA introduced Karyo as a part of Kyoho-no-kaikaku (Kyoho reform).

sen.j: ことから、徳川吉宗の享保の改革の一環として過料が導入されたという学説が存在していた。
sen.e: Therefore, the scholars theorized the administration of Yoshimune TOKUGAWA introduced a Karyo, forming a part of the Kyoho-no-kaikaku (Kyoho reform).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, the scholars theorized the administration of Yoshimune TOKUGAWA introduced a Karyo, forming a part of the Kyoho-no-kaikaku (Kyoho reform).

sen.j: が、元和 (日本)2年10月13日 (旧暦)（1616年）付で出された煙草に関する禁令には既に煙草栽培を行った農民及び同地の代官に過料を課していた（『東武実録』）。
sen.e: A challenging example of this was the ban on tobacco issued on November 21, 1616; this ban stated any farmer growing tobacco and a daikan (a local governor) with administration of the territory in which the farmer resided, shall be imposed a penalty fine, Karyo. (Source, "Tobu Jitsuroku")
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The ban on tobacco issued on November 21, 1616 had already stated that any farmer growing tobacco and a daikan (a local governor) with administration of the territory in which the farmer resided shall be imposed Karyo ("Tobu Jitsuroku").
sen.cmt: A challenging～wasの部分を除き一文にしました。 stated→had already stated とし、Sourceを除きました。
sen.e: The ban on tobacco issued on November 21, 1616 had already stated that any farmer growing tobacco and a daikan (a local governor) with administration of the territory in which the farmer resided shall be imposed Karyo ("Tobu Jitsuroku").

sen.j: 江戸幕府初期から過料は個別の法令で行われていた。
sen.e: In conclusion, Karyo had been a means of punishment in independent cases since the early Edo Bakufu period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In conclusion, Karyo had been a means of punishment in individual cases since the early period of Edo Bakufu.
sen.cmt: independent→individual, Edo Bakufu period→period of Edo Bakufu, としました。
sen.e: In conclusion, Karyo had been a means of punishment in individual cases since the early period of Edo Bakufu.

sen.j: もっとも、徳川吉宗が定めた『公事方御定書』によって過料の体系化が行われたのも事実である。
sen.e: Of course, it was under the direction of Yoshimune TOKUGAWA that Karyo was systemized, forming the rules of Kujigata-osadamegaki.
Of course, it is also fact that Karyo was systematized under Kujigata-osadamegaki (the law of Edo bakufu) provided by Yoshimune TOKUGAWA.
sen.cmt: it is also fact thatを加え、「公事方御定書」の補足を加えました。
sen.e: Of course, it is also fact that Karyo was systematized under Kujigata-osadamegaki (the law of Edo bakufu) provided by Yoshimune TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 同法によれば過料には3貫文もしくは5貫文の（一般的な）「過料」、10貫文の「重き過料」、本人の財力に応じた「身上に応じ過料」、本人の家の規模（財力に準じる）に応じた「小間に応じ過料」、地域単位で罰する場合石高に応じた「村高に応じ過料」の5つの事例に整理された。
sen.e: According to the law of Kujigata-osadamegaki, the penalty of Karyo (fines) was organized into five cases; "A (general) Karyo" was three kanmon (1,000 kanmon = 10,000 yen, 3 kanmon = 30 yen) or five kanmon (5 kanmon = 50 yen); "A heavy Karyo" was ten kanmon (10 kanmon = 100 yen); "Karyo adjusted by wealth (or fortune)" was dependent on a person's financial position (or wealth); "Karyo adjusted by Koma (a small room which used as a measurement unit to calculate the scale of the house.)" was dependent on the scale of the person's household (adjusted by wealth); "A Karyo adjusted by Muradaka (total yields of a village)" was dependent on Kokudaka (a system for determining land value for tribute purposes in the Edo period) of the region when law enforcement would punish a particular region in total.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: According to the law of Kujigata-osadamegaki, the penalty of Karyo was organized into five cases; 'Karyo' was three kanmon (3 kanmon = 30 yen) or five kanmon (5 kanmon = 50 yen); 'A heavy Karyo' was ten kanmon (10 kanmon = 100 yen); 'Karyo adjusted by wealth (or fortune)' was dependent on a personal financial position (or wealth); 'Karyo adjusted by Koma (a small room which used as a measurement unit to calculate the scale of the house)' was dependent on the scale of the personal household (adjusted by wealth); 'A Karyo adjusted by Muradaka (total yields of a village)' was dependent on Kokudaka (a system for determining land value for tribute purposes in the Edo period) of the region when law enforcement would punish a particular region in total.
sen.cmt: クオーテーションマークを修正、person's→personal としました。

sen.j: 賭博や売春をはじめ軽微な犯罪に対する刑罰として用いられた。
sen.e: Karyo was used as a penal punishment for minor crimes such as gambling and prostitution.

sen.e: Karyo was used as a penal punishment for minor crimes such as gambling and prostitution.
Karyo was used as a penal punishment for minor crimes such as gambling and prostitution.

sen.j: なお、納付期限は原則として言い渡されてから3日以内とされ、その期間内に納付されない場合には代替として手鎖の刑が課された。
sen.e: In addition, as a general rule, the deadline for payment was in three days after receiving the order, and the obligated person shall be imposed a tegusari penalty (confinement to one's residence and restraint in behavior with handcuffs on the wrists) if the person would not pay the fines by the deadline.

In addition, as a general rule, the deadline for payment was within three days after receiving the order, and the obligated person was imposed a tegusari penalty (confinement to one's residence and restraint in behavior with handcuffs on the wrists) if the person did not pay a fine by the deadline.
sen.cmt: shall be→was, in→within, would→did としました。
sen.e: In addition, as a general rule, the deadline for payment was within three days after receiving the order, and the obligated person was imposed a tegusari penalty (confinement to one's residence and restraint in behavior with handcuffs on the wrists) if the person did not pay a fine by the deadline.

sen.j: 更に戸〆（謹慎）などと過料が併せて課される場合もあった。
sen.e: Furthermore, in some cases, Karyo was imposed with Tojime [a punishment by nailing down a gate (or a front door)] of the house or was imposed with Kinshin (a punishment of being confined to one's house, house arrest) to the person committed a crime.
Furthermore, in some cases, Karyo was imposed with Tojime (house arrest, a punishment by nailing down a gate [or a front door]) to the person committed a crime.
sen.cmt: 括弧を修正、原文の通り（謹慎）の部分は単語のみ括弧内に入れて文章は除きました。
sen.e: Furthermore, in some cases, Karyo was imposed with Tojime (house arrest, a punishment by nailing down a gate [or a front door]) to the person committed a crime.

sen.j: 『公事方御定書』以後従来の過酷な刑罰を緩和する意味で実刑の代替として過料もたは他刑との二重仕置が課される事例が増加していくようになった。
sen.e: After the issuance of Kujigata-osadamegaki, the administration of Edo Bakufu was intent on making the old severe penal punishments less strict; instead of imposing one jail sentence, the administrator or law enforcements increased the number of orders, joining two punishments with Karyo, and another punishment.

After the issuance of "Kujigata-osadamegaki," a number of the cases imposed double punishment, Karyo and another punishment, had been increased as a substitute for a prison sentence to make the old severe penal punishments less strict.

sen.e: After the issuance of "Kujigata-osadamegaki," a number of the cases imposed double punishment, Karyo and another punishment, had been increased as a substitute for a prison sentence to make the old severe penal punishments less strict.

sen.j: また、藩法や村法などにおいても過料が行われており江戸時代を通じて広く行われていた。
sen.e: In addition, Karyo was widely used for Hanpo (laws and regulations to govern a feudal domain during the Edo period) and for Muraho (laws and regulations to govern a village) through the Eedo period.

sen.j: 刑罰（財産法）としての過料は明治2年（1869年）に明治政府が定めた『新律綱領』によって一旦廃止されて旧律令法の贖銅制度に基づく罰金制度に変更された。
sen.e: The Meiji government issued "Shinritsu Koryo (Outline of the New Criminal Code)" in '1869' this new code repealed Karyo (過料) as a penal punishment (punishment by seizing assets); the code changed Karyo (過料) into a penal fine system based on the Shokudo system of the old Ritsuryo law.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Karyo as a penal punishment (punishment by seizing assets) was abolished once by "Shinritsu Koryo" (Outline of the New Criminal Code) issued by the Meiji government in 1869 and changed to a penal fine system based on the Shokudo system of the old Ritsuryo law.
sen.cmt: 日本語表記、その他原文に無く不要と思われる箇所を除きました。
sen.e: Karyo as a penal punishment (punishment by seizing assets) was abolished once by "Shinritsu Koryo" (Outline of the New Criminal Code) issued by the Meiji government in 1869 and changed to a penal fine system based on the Shokudo system of the old Ritsuryo law.

sen.j: しかし、明治13年（1880年）の旧刑法によって刑罰である科料と分離された現行の過料が改めて設置されることとなった。
sen.e: However, this Current Karyo (過料), a non-penal fine, was newly established when the Meiji government issued the old penal code in 1880; it was departed from a petty fine (Karyo, 科料), which was a penal fine.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the current Karyo which was a non-penal fine and departed from a petty fine was newly established by the old penal code issued in 1880.
